description: This course provides an overview of human development across the lifespan. Phases of the life span covered include: the prenatal period, infancy, early childhood, middle and late childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, middle adulthood, and late adulthood. Development is examined from a variety of theoretical perspectives including biological, psychoanalytic, cognitive, behavioral, and systems. The leading models of development are critiqued and the unique perspectives and biases that are inherent in any given view are addressed. Cross-cultural perspectives and contemporary issues in lifespan human development, especially those related to health, are emphasized.
name: HUMAN DEVELOPMENT

values.comments:
This course provides an overview of human development across the lifespan. Phases of the life span covered include: the prenatal period, infancy, early childhood, middle and late childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, middle adulthood, and late adulthood. Development is examined from a variety of theoretical perspectives including biological, psychoanalytic, cognitive, behavioral, and systems. The leading models of development are critiqued and the unique perspectives and biases that are inherent in any given view are addressed. Cross-cultural perspectives and contemporary issues in lifespan human development, especially those related to health, are emphasized.

Students commented that the course covered a disproportionately large amount of material for a class that met one day per week. While most students characterized the course material as “interesting,” and “important,” many were critical of the class overall.

This class was co-taught by Professors Lewis and McCool. Students felt that the professors often repeated information almost verbatim from the textbook making the lectures very dry. Many students also felt that there were too many guest lecturers. They were further annoyed that the lectures often ran over the allotted time. In addition, students were disappointed that the professors did not hold regular office hours or review sessions which made the professors relatively inaccessible to students.

Students agreed that the course had a heavy workload. Readings were long and tedious; tests were generally too specific and bordering on “unfair.” Students were given a quiz at the beginning of each class. Many students chose to leave immediately after the quiz since they felt that lectures were a pointless repetition of the text. One student commented, “Memorization of the textbook is key! Going to class… not so much.” Despite student dissatisfaction with the course, it is a requirement for all nursing students.
